Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Human Behavior Assessment from Internet Usage: Foundations, Applications and Algorithms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human interaction with computers, and especially with the Internet, is ever increasing. As a consequence the field of cyber-psychology, which studies the thinking, behavior and attitudes of the person using the computer, is of growing importance. To date, studies in cyber-psychology have collected Internet usage data by means of self-reported surveys only, an approach which suffers from a number of drawbacks including human error, bias due to user concerns relating to social desirability, and limits on the volume and dimensionality of the data obtained. The PI's vision in this project is to advance human behavior assessment based on real Internet usage data, that is to say Internet usage data collected continuously, passively and unobtrusively without manual intervention while carefully maintaining user privacy expectations. To these ends, the PI will develop practical foundations, create two Internet enabled applications (one relating to online mental healthcare and the other to online socializing), and leverage results in behavioral psychology to design classification algorithms that demonstrate the ability to achieve significant insights and to detect behavioral similarities (relating to symptoms of depression and preferences in social contacts) based on Internet usage. The project builds on the PI's preliminary work that exploited real Internet usage data collected from Cisco NetFlow records to identify fine-grained Internet usage features associated with symptoms of depression, and will be executed with college students as primary subjects. The PI will collaborate in the current project with experts from the psychological and social sciences, clinical psychiatry, and the FBI's cyber crimes division. Outcomes will include an accurate characterization of Internet usage minimally affected by error and bias, and a large number of Internet usage features of high granularity for assessing human behavior, which together will yield insights and conclusions readily adaptable for practical utility.

Broader Impacts: This research will advance our ability to assess human behavior based on Internet usage data. The online mental healthcare application will yield Internet enabled proactive, early and cost -effective mental health care to complement care in existing clinical settings, while the online socializing application will lead to improved online social experiences by leveraging mutual social preferences. Applications of the research to mitigating Internet fraud and detecting cyber bullying are immediate. The PI will collaborate with HBCU and RUI institutions as well as K-12 schools to further enhance project outreach.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advances the field of cyber-psychology, which is the study of how physiological phenomena are associated with, and impacted via emerging computing technologies. In this broad realm, this project specifically addresses the issue of how to assess human behavior from mining and processing multiple sources of digital data, including statistics of Internet usage, wearable devices and social media. Specific outcomes of this project include a) algorithms to assess negative mood via processing statistics of Internet usage data; b) algorithms to determine cognitive and physical capabilities of humans using a combination of sensors emplaced on the human body and in the ambient infrastructure; and c) assessment of citizen engagement and perception from social media usage in the realm of public policy.

Intellectual merit: The project advances data mining and algorithmic foundations as pertaining to Internet usage, inertial sensory data, and social media usage. Novel features (most of which are highly preserving) are outcomes of the project that yield techniques to assess human behavior as demonstrated via various computing platforms. In addition, a number of machine learning techniques have been designed and adapted in a context-specific manner for operating under energy, latency and privacy considerations using knowledge of features extracted before. Careful attention has been paid to understanding the social impacts of the technologies developed so that permeance of project outcomes in the real-world can be rapid. These include privacy perceptions, ease of technology use, social perspectives on reliability of the algorithmic outcomes, and operational cost.

Broader Impact: This project advances our ability to assess human mood based on processing privacy-preserving Internet usage statistics. This enables overcomes critical challenges today in mental healthcare, two of which are the inability to assess symptoms remotely, and the ensuing high cost of care. By designing a platform for remote and cost-effective assessment of symptoms, this project advances low-cost and quality mental healthcare. Secondly, this project advances ability of healthcare professionals to assess cognitive abilities of citizens (especially senior citizens) using wearable computing technologies. This outcome also has broader impact for care delivery for patients with healthcare problems like dementia and cardio-vascular diseases. Finally, this project also advances the ability to glean insights on citizen engagement via social media, as it impacts public policy, outcomes of which will help agencies make superior civic decisions. Multiple graduate and undergraduate students have been trained in various R&D activities to help them gain a competitive edge in their chosen professions.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/29/2019
Modified by: Sriram Chellappan
